title: Section processing failed: "canonical block unknown" on upgrade to v1.10
body:
#### System information

Geth version: v1.10.1
OS & Version: Ubuntu 20.04, but Geth is running inside the official docker image. 

The node was synced using Geth v1.9.25, and I just changed the docker image hoping to re-use the same chain data. 

I was running the node with an 8 GB RAM cap, but since getting the error, I increased it to 9 GB to see if that helped the issue. 

I also have ~100GB of SSD space left. 

Happy to answer any other questions. 

#### Actual behaviour
We are getting a `canonical block unknown` error. 

The error message appears after one of two possible info messages. Either a message which imports a new chain segment, or after it tries to upgrade the chain index. 

`geth              | 2021-03-14T16:23:15.030909637Z INFO [03-14|16:23:15.030] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1      txs=146      mgas=12.487 elapsed=2.268s      mgasps=5.504  number=12037750 hash="2110a4…f103a1" dirty=106.87MiB
geth              | 2021-03-14T16:23:15.582995709Z ERROR[03-14|16:23:15.582] Section processing failed                type=bloombits               error="canonical block #12029091 unknown"
`

`geth              | 2021-03-14T16:23:20.789550303Z INFO [03-14|16:23:20.789] Upgrading chain index                    type=bloombits               percentage=99
geth              | 2021-03-14T16:23:21.546963205Z ERROR[03-14|16:23:21.546] Section processing failed                type=bloombits               error="canonical block #12029091 unknown"
`

Even though I'm getting this error, though, geth continues to deep freeze and import blocks to the head of the chain:
`geth              | 2021-03-14T16:27:23.727250541Z INFO [03-14|16:27:23.727] Deep froze chain segment                 blocks=4      elapsed=2.359s      number=11947769 hash="a22a0e…4ead1f"
`

`geth              | 2021-03-14T16:27:28.382467746Z INFO [03-14|16:27:28.382] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1      txs=236      mgas=12.331 elapsed=4.692s      mgasps=2.628  number=12037770 hash="878008…56645a" dirty=141.76MiB
`

And also seems to continue generating the snapshot syncs:

`geth              | 2021-03-14T16:27:28.365493301Z INFO [03-14|16:27:28.365] Aborting state snapshot generation       root="45d191…3a66a4" in="0ac347…207cb5" at="87f4e8…734135" accounts=5119345 slots=20326591 storage=1.78GiB elapsed=13m16.055s  eta=1572h4m16.038s
geth              | 2021-03-14T16:27:28.366673341Z INFO [03-14|16:27:28.366] Resuming state snapshot generation       root="fca3d8…9c5c61" in="0ac347…207cb5" at="87f4e8…734135" accounts=5119345 slots=20326591 storage=1.78GiB elapsed=13m16.056s  eta=1572h4m23.147s
`

(Is this something to be worried about?)

Did your node ever crash that could explain some missing data? Do you have some startup logs to share? Could you try to explicitly load up that unknown blocks via `eth_getBlock` and see what is produces?

@karalabe 

OK - it seems to have worked! 
`geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146086900Z ########## BAD BLOCK #########
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146101051Z Chain config: {ChainID: 1 Homestead: 1150000 DAO: 1920000 DAOSupport: true EIP150: 2463000 EIP155: 2675000 EIP158: 2675000 Byzantium: 4370000 Constantinople: 7280000 Petersburg: 7280000 Istanbul: 9069000, Muir Glacier: 9200000, Berlin: 12244000, YOLO v3: <nil>, Engine: ethash}
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146399648Z 
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146411759Z Number: 12050728
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146429651Z Hash: 0x5b00907b2a197f53995fecdf51ca49a80c8a542d2c15539a3efe6294381531ff
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146441712Z 
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146453545Z 
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146465323Z Error: unknown ancestor
geth              | 2021-03-16T16:33:28.146476935Z ##############################
`

But it seems to have recovered after that, and am now importing new block headers and receipts, and `eth.getBlock` now has a block for 12029091 (and beyond). 

Do I need to worry about the snapshots I generated with the bad block? Or should those be taken care of automatically?

Thanks!
EDIT: Looks like geth automatically cleared and restarted the snapshot generation. Should be good to go! Thanks!
